item.title: The worst myth of remote work
item.description:
Oh that single perfect distraction free place for remote work.

The worst myth of remote work is that you need a different (perfect) place outside office to get the most work done, every single day.

There are several places outside of your office with few or no distractions. Like these places.

But if you spend more time in your day finding that perfect place instead of actually working, you are working (remotely) wrongly .

Remote work is about productivity. Stick to one spot and get work done.

item.title: A simple rule to Pricing
item.description:
According to some economists, consumers with low elasticity of demand should be charged at a higher price.

While the consumers with high elasticity of demand should be charged at a low price.

A better question is, how do you determine of the elasticity of demand for your product?

item.title: Finding Remote Programmers
item.description:
First, you need to be able to find good programmers. 

Next, you need trust and good communication.

Then, your remote programmers require discipline.

And last but not least, you need to judge the remote programmers’ work based on work itself.

Can you do it?

item.title: Best places to get work done
item.description:
In my opinion, these are the best places to get work done.

  1. My apartment’s room
  2. Coffeeshop with my mobile broadband
  3. Library
  4. Church
  5. Schools or University
  6. My ex-company’s office
  7. Any quiet corners with wifi available

It’s not the office but the people and their actions that disrupt work.

As long as the place has few distractions and has internet access, I’m happy to sit down and get some work done.

I also find it a mistake to take longer to travel to your favourite spot just to get work done. Remote work should reduce travelling as much as possible. It’s the work that is important here.
